review: This almost fully replaced my Roku2. With the exception of a few lacks, and a few issues with the UI, it is a great joy.The good:Youtube works better on it than it ever will on Roku. The only exception is Youtube constantly asking me to sign-in/link to see videos.The UI in general for frequently used programs is niceThe ability to side-load things onto it that aren't available on Amazon.The vast majority of things.The bad:I can't get the one app I really want on it, but this is their fault, not Amazons. Amazon has given me a little wiggle room in their side-loading, but it doesn't make it a lot better.The UI can get clunky finding anything beyond what it wants me to see. Luckily most of what I look for is Netflix and games, but I would love the ability to trim the menus and get it a bit slimmer. And the lack of the ability to change the UI makes it a bit annoying in that we have to go to 3-4 different menus, and enter a password, just to run applications we have installed. This is an unreasonable pain.So really, if they just fixed up the UI a bit? This device would be pretty much perfect. I do worry about gifting one out though, as it would probably come pre-configured as me, so I am thinking I might end up getting my friends a gift card or something with instructions: "Go buy this."
author: J. Kelly

review: I read a number of the reviews on this item and I was just a little skeptical...we have Comcast and I know how expensive it can be to rent/buy movies.  One of the reviews was from a woman who also had Comcast and raved about how much of a difference this Amazon Fire TV has made.  So I decided to give it a try...luckily Amazon was offering a reduced cost for Prime members and that's just what I was looking for.  WHAT A GREAT FIND!  This was not only extremely easy to set-up but once set-up, exceeded my expectations.  Even my husband was impressed when I walked him through it.  I am so glad I gave in & purchased the Amazon Fire TV...now I can watch anything I already own on my Kindle plus my Prime Instant Video selections for movies/TV.  Definitely recommend this item!!

review: First, a perspective: I own an Apple TV (3rd gen/720p), Roku 3, and Chromecast.  We've been Prime Members (two in our household each paying $79 now $99/year) since its inception.  We spend a ton with Amazon, own multiple Kindles, and have a large (purchased) Amazon Music library.I purchased the Fire TV (locally at Best Buy) when we added a TV in our basement and I needed to "back fill" streaming on a lightly-used spare bedroom TV.Unboxing: the package is quite heavy compared to the other products.  This is obviously due to the quality device (as an aside, while substantial, the remote isn't as hefty as I thought it would be).  Note to folks with wall-mounted TV's and small spaces - weight could prove to be an issue finding a place for Fire TV (we hang the Roku on the back of another TV and the cables do a fine job holding it up).  Another note: like all similar devices, there are no wall screw holes - it's just shiny black plastic on top/edges and dull plastic on the bottom.Now for the punchline (and the most important reason that I returned it after two days) - PBS Kids (and other kids channels) are for-fee in a subscription.  This is NOT trivial: with a couple kids (separate profiles), this comes out to $119.88 per year.  This was a key reason for purchasing the device - kids shows.Yes, ESPN, Netflix and other services are here.  But the "binding" to "Amazon first" and differentiation via gaming (plus need for a $50 controller) tipped the scales to other devices.Other annoyances:- The remote isn't as natural to use as I've come to expect from Amazon's hardware (Kindle, Kindle Fire, etc.)- The video quality wasn't as good as other services- I felt "bound" to Amazon's library and services.  Kind of like Kindle Fire (tablet) drives to Kindle books first.- "Watch Disney Junior" is an "app".  It's a "purchase".  I actually have it in my queue to "review".  On Apple TV and Roku, it's a channel.
